conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the oil droplets and their motion to determine the proportionality constant k.
Initially, both droplets A and B fall with a uniform velocity v0 through a distance h1 in time t.
Since the droplets are moving at a constant velocity, the net force acting on them is zero, so gravitational force is balanced by air resistance: m0 g = k m0^(1/3) v0.
When the voltage U is applied, droplet B moves upwards with a uniform velocity v1 through a distance h2 in time t.
The forces acting on B are gravitational force, air resistance, and electric force due to the voltage.
Since B moves upwards with a constant velocity, the net force is zero, so qE = m0 g + k m0^(1/3) v1.
Determine the charge q from the motion of droplet B: q U/d = m0 g + k m0^(1/3) v1.
Both droplets move through their respective distances in the same time t.
Relate v0 and v1 to h1 and h2: v0 = h1/t, v1 = h2/t.
Substitute v0 into the equation from Step 1: m0 g = k m0^(1/3) h1/t.
Solve for k: k = m0 g t / (m0^(1/3) h1).
The proportionality constant k is given by k = g t / (m0^(2/3) h1).
